description: Large white and red peonies on branches with leaves blowing in the wind. Large white peony to center left, with bud immediately above. Large red peony at right edge slightly above center.
medium: Hanging scroll; ink and color on silk
text: In an unusually detailed way, but without losing any of their decorative effects, two peonies are captured, being blown violently in a summer rain storm. The waving diagonals of clouds in the background suggest that storm clouds are moving quickly across the sky. Sakai Ho_itsu was not only a painter, but also a poet and man of letters. He came from a high-level samurai family, but chose to enter priesthood at the age of thirty-six rather than following a political career. Ho_itsu enjoyed a very good education and trained himself in the styles of Chinese masters and ukiyo-e painters. After 1797, however, he devoted himself solely to the Rinpa school with the aim of reviving the style of Ko_rin. Ko_rin had worked for the Sakai family five generations before, which gave Ho_itsu the opportunity to study his works in depth. Ho_itsu was truly devoted to Ko_rin, but did not simply copy his style, instead he perfected it by combining it with techniques from other contemporary painting schools.
title: Peonies in the Wind
